title: Honeymoon over for NAB as rising compensation bill bites
text:
Back in May when the afterglow surrounding Mr Chronican’s stewardship was most pronounced and the stock was trading at $25.83 there were as many as 11 buys.

Morgan Stanley’s Richard Wiles unveiled a ‘tactical underweight’ on October 2, saying the research department expected the share price to fall over the next 60 days.

Capital is front of mind for Mr Wiles and other analysts who are concerned that after the higher-than-expected remediation charge the targeted common equity tier 1 ratio of 10.5 per cent will prove elusive.

“We downgrade our rating to underweight and move it to number four in our major bank order of preference as we believe the outlook for revenue is deteriorating,” Mr Wiles said in a note to clients.

“Further transformation program re-investment is needed, loan losses are drifting up, further capital build is necessary, there is risk of another dividend cut in FY20 and trading multiples are now full.”

Since the GFC we estimate NAB's dividend has exceeded its statutory EPS in six of the 11 years — Jonathan Mott, UBS

UBS analyst and bank bear Jonathan Mott was even more savage, pointing out the bank had now incurred $18.8 billion spread across 52 non-recurring items since 1997.

“Over the last 22 years these ‘large and noteable’ items have averaged 14.4 per cent of all cash profit, with this trend accelerating to 24 per cent of cash profit since the financial crisis,” Mr Mott said.

Advertisement

“The NAB Board has tended to look through these 'large and lumpy' items when determining the dividend policy. Since the GFC we estimate NAB's dividend has exceeded its statutory EPS in six of the 11 years.”

Bell Potter analyst TS Lim said he was surprised by the magnitude of the provision and lowered his 12-month price forecast by $1.18 from $30.20 to $29.02.

Mr Lim said in a note to clients the provision would allow the team to focus on making the MLC transaction as smooth as possible and would allow incoming CEO Ross McEwan to focus on the core business.

“This outcome does not take into account higher APRA TLAC and RBNZ capital proposals down the track and there is the risk of a capital raising at the full year result to ensure a reasonable prudential buffer,” he wrote to clients.

Macquarie’s Mr German reduced his NAB recommendation from overweight to neutral in late September following a powerful rally through a 12-month high and towards the $30 a share mark.

Mr German said in a note to clients dated September 25 that Macquarie was “hitting the pause button” after the rally reduced the longstanding discount to its peers and was “trading in line with its theoretical value”.
description: Enthusiasm for the once-popular pick has waned after the bank revealed a $1.2 billion rise in its compensation bill.
